Description: (Lighthouse|Wreck|NULL) Landmark for navigation visible from the sea.
(Turret|NULL) Maritime beacon. Fixed or floating structure, intended to indicate a feature of interest for navigation (danger, obstacle, passage).
Most often, a cascade is the section where the water of a river no longer flows, but falls. It is a waterfall.
(Lighted Turret|NULL) A low-power, fixed or flashing light signaling pass entrances or alignments. It can be located on the ground, at the end of a mast or pylon, or on other structures.
(NULL) A structure comprising a water supply and, generally, a basin. A fountain can be natural if it is fed by a spring.
(NULL) A structure, covered or not, comprising a basin supplied with water, generally of natural origin, whose primary purpose was to allow for wetting, washing and rinsing laundry.
(Bog) Wetland, area covered by shallow waters, partly overgrown with vegetation.
(NULL) A place where a watercourse disappears totally or partially through seepage or into a sinkhole. All or part of the watercourse then becomes underground.
(Reservoir|Trough|Well|NULL) Any natural or artificial body of water which has a place name or which needs to be designated and which cannot be classified as another 'Nature' of Hydrographic Point.

(NULL) Point of emergence at the ground surface of a watercourse after an underground course. A resurgence is an exsurgence fed by at least one identified surface watercourse, part or all of which infiltrates the subsoil through one or more sinkholes.
(NULL) Point of emergence at the ground surface of water stored inside, without knowledge of an upstream open-air path.
(NULL) Installation for capturing a spring. A captured spring can be represented in Nature="Fountain" when a basin is constructed at the level of its capture.
